Award.AwardTitle: Model Reduction and Statistical Closure of Turbulent Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop and apply a new methodology of model reduction and statistical closure for deterministic, nonlinear dynamical systems. The overall objective of this work is to derive coarse-grained equations that approximate the effect of interactions between resolved and unresolved scales of motion from given, fine-grained, physical equations of motion. For a typical complex system, say a Hamiltonian system with many degrees of freedom, the method of reduction proceeds as follows: a vector of resolved variables is selected to describe the coherent, slow behavior of the system, and a parametric statistical model is canonically associated with this resolved vector; the predicted, or estimated, evolution of the mean resolved vector is defined by that path in the statistical parameter space which optimally fits the Liouville equation for the given dynamics. A cost functional is introduced to quantify the lack-of-fit of parameter paths; it is an information-theoretic metric on the Liouville residual containing weights that determine the adjustable constants in the ensuing closure. The desired equation for the mean resolved vector is derived by applying Hamilton-Jacobi theory to the optimization principle defining the best-fit closure. Recently the best-fit theory has been validated on a prototypical turbulent dynamics (truncated Burgers-Hopf equation), for which it produces a coarse-grained dynamics having novel dissipative effects and modified nonlinear interactions. Effective coarse-grained equations will be derived for barotropic and baroclinic quasi-geostrophic flows, and these closures will be tested against benchmark numerical simulations of fully-resolved ensembles. The best-fit approach will also be applied to represent approximate nonequilibrium spectra for these models, after first investigating these questions on some simpler turbulent wave dynamics.

Mathematical models of many physical phenomena such as geophysical fluid dynamics, which are used to predict the motions of the Earth's atmosphere and oceans, typically display very complex, turbulent, behavior. It is therefore important to design appropriate reduced models of such complex systems that capture, at least approximately, the coherent behavior of the full system in many fewer variables. The P.I.'s research is directed towards developing general mathematical and statistical tools for constructing reduced models of this kind. Specifically, the research endeavors to simplify nonlinear dynamical models of the atmosphere and oceans by devising effective computational schemes in which unresolved turbulence is parameterized by statistical models that best fit the full equations of motion. A reduction method of this kind would furnish a mathematically justified technique for improving the performance of numerical models of the large-scale, low-frequency dynamics of weather and climate. Specifically, the work seeks to build up an understanding of model reduction and closure through a hierarchy of simplified, prototype problems examined using a systematic and robust methodology that draws on physical concepts from nonequilibrium statistical mechanics and thermodynamics, mathematical techniques from optimization theory and dynamical systems, as well as tools from statistics and information theory. A postdoctoral research associate will be hired to collaborate with the P.I., and the training of the postdoc in these interrelated topics will be an important outcome of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project addressed a central question in the applied mathematical sciences --- namely, the construction of reduced models of complex dynamical systems.  Contemporary science often employs mathematical descriptions of physical phenomena that involve a very large number of variables, or degrees of freedom.  One prominent example is fluid turbulence, in which the flow field is extremely intricate and apparently random, even though it is governed by a known system of deterministic equations of motion.   For such dynamical systems it is desirable to devise reduced descriptions that involve far fewer variables, called the relevant or resolved variables, and yet account for the influence of the many ignored variables in an approximate manner.    With this motivation the project drew on ideas and techniques from statistical mechanics to derive reduced equations for the mean, or average, values of a set of relevant variables from the equations governing an underlying physical problem.  

The main novelty of the approach developed by the investigators is a characteriation of the evolution of the mean relevant variables in terms of the information loss rate that results from replacing the full dynamical system by a statistical-dynamical model determined by the selected relevant variables.   Specifically, the new theory calculates the best-fit path in the parameter space of the reduced model using a statistical metric that measures the departure between the model evolution and the full complex evolution.   This characterization furnishes important links between the reduction strategy and key concepts in both statistics (information metrics) and thermodynamics (entropy production).     Moreover, it ensures that the resulting reduced dynamical equations have the generic structure of equations arising in nonequilibrium thermodynamics, that is, the natural structure for describing macroscopic phenomena.  

The investigators implemented this general reduction strategy on a set of prototype problems, chosen to demonstrate the strengths and weakness of the method.    Two of these problems were simplified versions of fluid mechanics, traditionally used by theorists as testbeds that mimic the more complicated behavior of actual fluids; specifically, a shell model of turbulence, and the Burgers equation.    A third application was to two-dimensional fluid dynamics, a context that has implications for modeling phenomena that occur in the atmosphere or oceans on the rotating Earth.   In each test problem, the predictive equations of the reduction were deduced by analytical methods, and then the skill of the reduced model was benchmarked against computationally intensive simulations of the full underlying dynamics.    These tests demonstrated that the much simpler reduced models are capable of predicting the essential features of the turbulent flows to within a reasonable approximation, but with orders of magnitude less cost in computational time and memory space.  In all three scenarios, good approximations to the evolution of the relevant variables were obtained, provided that the many unresolved variables were assumed to follow equilibrium statistics.  Under this restriction the efficacy of the reduction strategy based on minimum information loss rate was validated.  

A significant benefit of deriving the reduced equations in this manner is that they do not contain any free model parameters that must be tuned to data.   This highly desirable property of the new "optimal closure" contrasts with all prior turbulence closures, which rely on some empirical fitting.    The completed work leaves open, however, the question of whether such an intrinsic closure would be possible without the restriction that the unresolved, or ignored, degrees of freedom lie in statistical equilibrium.   This assumption, though natural in some situations, limits the range of application of the approach in the broader context of turbulence, where nonequilibrium cascades of energy require appropriate statistical modeling.     

The project involved a postdoctoral associate, who was employed full-time for two years under grant funding.   The postdoc contributed fully to the research program and collaborated on all the publications completed during the funded period.   The PI and postdoc presented their findings at several seminars and conferences in the fields of applied mathematics, fluid mechanics and statistical thermodynamics.   The PI also mentored a doctoral student, who successfully developed and implemented the optimal closure approach in another fluid dynamical context -- the dynamics of ensembles of many point vortices in the plane, and extensions to geophysical fluid dynamics.
